entry.title: Do you know that your email address is shared by default with your network on LinkedIn?
entry.summary: Your email address is visible by default to your network, you may not want that.
entry.content:
TL;DR: You should hide your email to your network on LinkedIn.

You can easily find your connections' email addresses. Go on their profiles and click on "See contact info".

How to hide your email?

Your email is, by default, visible to your network. You can change this setting in "Me" > "Settings & Privacy" > "Privacy". Change "Who can see your email address" to "Only you".

Why does it matter?

I believe that with a little of social engineering you can add anyone on LinkedIn, even if you don't know them. Any strangers can be one of your connections so it is important to protect your email address!

With your email address in the wild, here are some of the risks:

  • You may recieve (more) spams
  • It may be used for social engineering
  • You may be the target of some ransomware

Some statistics from my network

Since GDPR you can download your data which is a good thing. In LinkedIn, you can do it here. In the archive generated, you will find a Connections.csv file with all your connections included their email adsresses... Yep, so here is some statistics from my own network (about 600 connections):

  • 71% share their personal email (gmail, yahoo, hotmail...)
  • 27% other (mainly pro but also personal email with custom domain name)
  • 2% don't share their email.

Bonus: 50% of my contacts have a gmail address!

I know that some recruiters on LinkedIn have thousands of connections, I wonder if some of them extract email from LinkedIn that way.

entry.title: Create and deploy a Django project on Clever Cloud
entry.summary: How to deploy a Django project on Clever Cloud ?
entry.content:
In this blog post, we will see how to host a new Django project on Clever Cloud (www.clever-cloud.com). If you don't have a Clever Cloud account, you can signup and you will get a 20€ credit to test the platform ;)

1/ Create a Django project

$ django-admin startproject fooproject
$ git init
$ git add .
$ git commit -m "initial commit"

For more information, please take a look at the wonderful Django's documentation.

2/ Create the application on Clever Cloud

  1. Create a new application (Personal Space > Add an application)
  2. Create a brand new app
  3. Choose Python
  4. At the scaling step, choose what you want, if you don't know, just use the default settings
  5. Name your application, mine will by "Foo project"

And that's it !

3/ Deploy your application

Go to the Information section for your application and at the top you should see a line starting by git remote add ..., copy it. It may be one two lines actually if you have a small screen, eg. 13".

On your project then do:

$ git remote add clever git+ssh://git@push-par-clevercloud-customers.services.clever-cloud.com/app_00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000000.git
$ git push clever master

Come back to your Clever cloud dashboard and go to the Logs section and see your application deploying :) (You may want to scroll down to see the latest logs)

And you have done your first deploy !

4/ But the deploy failed :(

We missed some steps to ensure that the deploy run smoothly, mainly configuration steps. Let's go back to our Clever Cloud dashboard. Go the Environment variables section of your application and add the following variables:

PYTHON_VERSION=3
CC_PYTHON_MODULE=fooproject.wsgi:application

Then redeploy your application. At this point you should have a running application! Go see your application by using the link at the top corner right of the dashboard or go to http://<your_application_id>.cleverapps.io/

You will have a DisallowedHost error but at leat your application is running. We need to configure a bit Django by adding the following to the fooproject/settings.py:

ALLOWED_HOSTS = ['app-<your_application_id>.cleverapps.io', 'localhost', ]

Not sure here why, but you also have to add localhost as an allowed host.

Commit and push your new settings file, a new deploy should be triggered and you should be able to see your application :)

You should now have a deployed and running application.

5/ Use hooks for continuous integration

The deploy was quite easy so far, we just needed to deploy the new code on Clever cloud. But in reality, there is severals steps when you want to deploy Django.

In order to manage those differents steps we will use a bash script that will be executed after each build and before deploy.

First, add a new environment variable:

CC_POST_BUILD_HOOK=./post_build_hook.sh

The file post_build_hook.sh is at the root of our project, but you can put it where you want and/or use a different scripting language.

Put inside your file the following:

1
2
3
4
5
6
7
#!/bin/bash

# Script will exit if there is an error
set -e

./manage.py collectstatic --no-input
./manage.py migrate --no-input

In our case we take care to run the migration and collect the static before each deploy. You can imagine adding here ./manage.py test --no-input to be sure all your tests are green before going live.

Take a look at the hooks documentation if you want to tailor it to your project.

5/ Use a database

A few more steps to have a database for our project.

  1. On Clever cloud dashboard, click on Add an add-on
  2. Select PostgreSQL
  3. Select DEV plan, you will be able to change of plan later if needed
  4. Link your add-on to your application
  5. Give a name to your database

In your settings.py you can update your database credentials by using the following environment variables.

DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.postgresql',
        'NAME': os.environ.get('POSTGRESQL_ADDON_DB', ''),
        'USER': os.environ.get('POSTGRESQL_ADDON_USER', ''),
        'PASSWORD': os.environ.get('POSTGRESQL_ADDON_PASSWORD', ''),
        'HOST': os.environ.get('POSTGRESQL_ADDON_HOST', ''),
        'PORT': os.environ.get('POSTGRESQL_ADDON_PORT', ''),
    }
}

Commit those changes and push them in order to deploy again your application. At this point, thanks to the hook installed before, the deploy will create the schema inside your database with all its tables!

6/ Create a super user

Go to Profile then SSH Key and add your SSH key. After that you can ssh the server make the first migrations and create the super user.

ssh -t ssh@sshgateway-clevercloud-customers.services.clever-cloud.com <APP_ID>
cd <APP_ID>/
./manage.py createsuperuser

This should be the only time to need to connect with SSH to Clever Cloud. Please keep in mind that you should avoid SSH access as much as possible.

7/ Manage your static and medias files

It is important to understand that the notion of "static" files is different between Clever cloud and Django!

In Django there is a difference between the file uploaded with the project (static files) and the file uploaded by the users (media files) but for Clever cloud static files are all the files you want to serve statically.

In Django's settings add:

STATIC_URL = '/public/static/'
MEDIA_URL = '/public/media/'
MEDIA_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'public/media')
STATIC_ROOT = os.path.join(BASE_DIR, 'public/static')

Locally create the directory public and add a dummy hidden file .keep_this_dir for example in order the create this directory during the build on clever cloud.

For medias file create a new add-on "FS Bucket" on which your media files will be saved. And then, in Clever Cloud dashboard add the following environment variables:

STATIC_FILES_PATH=public/
STATIC_URL_PREFIX=/public
CC_FS_BUCKET=/public/media:...fsbucket.services.clever-cloud.com

Redeploy and you now have a Django project with your static files handled. You can go to the admin to check that for example.

Conclusion

I hope you have managed to deploy your own Django project on Clever Cloud. The service is really smooth and easy to use, congratz to the team!

entry.title: Marketplaces API, the key to onboard merchants
entry.summary: Having a good API will speed your merchants onboarding and time-to-market. On the contrary a bad API or no API can demotivate your merchants and make you and them lose money.
entry.content:
TL;DR: Having a good API will speed your merchants onboarding and time-to-market. On the contrary a bad API or no API can demotivate your merchants and make you and them lose money.


Why do you need a marketplace?

E-commerce has always been a big component of the internet as we know it. Having a website to sell your products is nowaday a requirement for a merchant and there is now a new trend to do marketplaces. Marketplace is simply a website that connect merchants to clients and behave as a trust tier. The most famous examples are Amazon, Zalando or Alibaba. One clue about marketplaces developments is the explosion of marketplace solutions that exists today, just to name a few : Mirakl, Izberg, Wizplace. Most of the merchants are using marketplace solution or custom solution in order to allow other merchant to sell on their own website and make it grow in term of products, traffic and turnover.

Why an API?

So you manage to sign contracts with some merchants who want to sell on your marketplace, congratulation ! Then, what? They will want to put some products quickly then generate and manage some orders. Most of marketplace solutions allow you to do it with their backoffice, so that’s cool, everything can go quite fast. But it requires for the merchant to dedicate some time to handle his products on your website and this potentially quite often. He will need to learn a new tools as he need to manage everything from your backoffice. While in the meantime, all merchants have already a software to manage this on their own, this can be an e-commerce solution (Prestashop, Magento, Shopify, ...) or an ERP (SAP, Sage, ...).

The API helps your merchant by allowing him to manage your marketplace from its favorite tool !

However, this cost money, consider it when your marketplace reach a minimum of merchants.

An API for everything, because automation rules

You now have an API for merchant, but does it handle everything the merchant need? For example on most of marketplace there is a list of categories on which the merchant can sell. This should not provided in a PDF or CSV file but as an API. Why? Because if tomorrow you want to add new categories with your API, you don’t have to communicate about it and merchants can easily retrieve them. With an API for everything you allow the merchant to automatise everything ! It means less friction points.

What’s a good/bad API?

A good API is a when your merchant is fully autonomous to plug your marketplace to its IT system. From my experience there is only a few marketplaces with good API. Here are some good and bad practices on marketplace API, those criterias are just a few among a long list, took a look at Vinay Sahni post "Best Practices for Designing a Pragmatic RESTful API" for more informations.

Good practices:

  • Having a nice documentation (mandatory!)
  • Autonomous merchant (don’t need to contact you for accessing the API for example)
  • Restful API
  • Standard format (JSON, XML, SOAP)
  • Clear errors (too often the error after an API call is not clear, this will cause the merchant to contact you and therefore lose time)
  • Status page (you will have downtime, communicate about it)
  • API backwards compatibility
  • Bonus: having SDK for main languages

Bad practices:

  • Complexe API (all the complexity should be handle by the marketplace, not the merchant)
  • Bad documentation (example, a simple “Javadoc” style documentation)
  • Fuzzy error (it will make lose time to everyone)
  • Breaking changes (no backward compatibility, merchants will have to update their development, they may not have the money/resources and therefore this is a big risk for business)

entry.title: How to get the list of French cities and more?
entry.summary: Open-data doesn't provide a list of french cities with zip codes and GPS coordinates. How can we retrieve them ?
entry.content:
Introduction

All I wanted was a DB of current french cities, their zip codes and their GPS coordinates. It turned out that it was not an easy thing to have !

Opendata in France (the source)

So in France we got some nice stuff about opendata since a few years, and that were I got my sources.

INSEE

For the list of current french cities, the only trusted source is INSEE. They provide that here https://www.insee.fr/fr/information/2028028 (direct link to 2017 data).

First thing to know:

Les compositions communales des zones d'emploi, aires urbaines et bassins de vie au 1er janvier 2017 proposées en téléchargement comportent quelques anomalies de classement concernant très peu de communes (moins d'une quinzaine). Une nouvelle mise en ligne, corrigeant ces anomalies, sera effectuée au début de l'automne.

Ok so the actual state agency in charge of listing this kind of data told us that there may be some errors in their files. That's a good start!

Some informations about the file:

  • Format: XLS
  • Size: ~10.4Mo
  • Number of cities: 35416
  • Last update: 2017
  • License: ?

This file will be our trusted source for current french cities. From this file we will extract from the tab "COM" only the first three columns (CODEGEO, LIBGEO and DEP) and put that into a CSV file encoding with UTF8 so we can read it easily.

La Poste / dataNOVA

For the list of zip code, we got to go "La Poste" website, because, yeah, it is another state agency that handle that. More precisely we go to dataNOVA, the subsidiary that manage all open data for La Poste group. The data can be found here https://datanova.legroupe.laposte.fr/explore/dataset/laposte_hexasmal/export/ (direct link to CSV)

Some informations about the file:

  • Format: CSV, JSON, XLS
  • Size: ~2.7Mo
  • Number of cities: 39202
  • Last update: ?
  • License: ODdL

This file will be our trusted source for zip codes. It also contains the GPS coordinates which can be useful!

The script

The script I made to merge data from INSEE and from La Poste.

import csv


INSEE_DATA = {}
LAPOSTE_DATA = {}
MERGED_DATA = {}


#
# STEP 1 Reading INSEE file
#
# It is quite easy, we just parse the file and put the data into a
# dictionnary which will be more practical to use after that.
#

with open('insee.csv', 'r') as insee_file:
    reader = csv.DictReader(insee_file, delimiter=';')
    for row in reader:
        code_insee = row['CODGEO']
        if code_insee not in INSEE_DATA:
            INSEE_DATA[code_insee] = {
                'name': row['LIBGEO'].strip(),
                'DEP': row['DEP'],
            }

print("Reading of INSEE file")
print("\t{} cities found.\n".format(len(INSEE_DATA)))


#
# STEP 2 Reading LAPOSTE file
#
# Not so easy here, I discarded former cities and cities with no GPS coordinates.
# Also some INSEE codes seem to be outdated and there some other stuff not good.
# This data set should not be considered as ready-to-use.
#

laposte_file = open('laposte_hexasmal.csv')
reader = csv.DictReader(laposte_file, delimiter=';')
count_city_without_gps = 0

for row in reader:
    code_insee = row['Code_commune_INSEE']
    if row['coordonnees_gps'] != '':
        gps_coordinates = row['coordonnees_gps']
    else:
        gps_coordinates = None
    zip_code = row['Code_postal']

    # Exceptions because LAPOSTE 'Code_commune_INSEE' is not up to date...
    marseille_codes_insee = ['13203', '13206', '13208', '13209', '13209',
                             '13211']
    paris_codes_insee = ['75103', '75107', '75119', '75111', '75112', '75115',
                         '75104', '75110', '75117', '75101', '75102', '75105',
                         '75106', '75108', '75109', '75113', '75120', '75114',
                         '75116', '75116', '75118']
    lyon_codes_insee = ['69389', '69381', '69382', '69384', '69388', '69385',
                        '69387', '69383', '69386']
    if code_insee in marseille_codes_insee:
        code_insee = '13055'    # Marseille
    elif code_insee in paris_codes_insee:
        code_insee = '75056'    # Paris
    elif code_insee in lyon_codes_insee:
        code_insee = '69123'    # Lyon
    elif code_insee == '80756':
        zip_code = '80560'      # Error in LAPOSTE file :(

    if not gps_coordinates:
        count_city_without_gps = count_city_without_gps + 1
    elif code_insee not in LAPOSTE_DATA:
        LAPOSTE_DATA[code_insee] = {
            'zipcodes': {
                zip_code: gps_coordinates,
            }
        }
    else:
        # Code INSEE already found

        if zip_code in LAPOSTE_DATA[code_insee]['zipcodes'].keys():
            # Same CODGEO and same zipcode -> same city
            pass
        elif zip_code[:2] in [z[:2] for z in LAPOSTE_DATA[code_insee]['zipcodes'].keys()]:
            # Seems like the same city but with different zipcode
            LAPOSTE_DATA[code_insee]['zipcodes'][zip_code] = gps_coordinates
        elif code_insee == '39274':
            # WTF, city: Lajoux with 2 zipcodes from different department
            LAPOSTE_DATA[code_insee]['zipcodes'][zip_code] = gps_coordinates
        elif code_insee == '91479':
            # WTF, city: Paray-Vieille-Poste with 2 zipcodes from different department
            LAPOSTE_DATA[code_insee]['zipcodes'][zip_code] = gps_coordinates
laposte_file.close()

print("Reading of LAPOSTE file")
print("\t{} cities found.".format(len(INSEE_DATA)))
print("\t{} cities discarded because of missing GPS coordinates.".format(count_city_without_gps))

cities_insee_not_laposte = []
for code_insee, name in INSEE_DATA.items():
    if code_insee in LAPOSTE_DATA:
        pass
    else:
        cities_insee_not_laposte.append(code_insee)

print("\t{} cities are missing in LAPOSTE file (because only present on the INSEE file, probably new cities)\n".format(len(cities_insee_not_laposte)))


#
# STEP 3 Merging INSEE and LAPOSTE file
#

deleted_cities = 0
for code_insee, city in LAPOSTE_DATA.items():
    if code_insee in INSEE_DATA:
        MERGED_DATA[code_insee] = LAPOSTE_DATA[code_insee]
        MERGED_DATA[code_insee]['verbose_name'] = INSEE_DATA[code_insee]['name']
        MERGED_DATA[code_insee]['department'] = INSEE_DATA[code_insee]['DEP']
    else:
        deleted_cities = deleted_cities + 1

print("Merging of INSEE and LAPOSTE files")
print("\t{} cities merged.".format(len(MERGED_DATA)))
print("\t{} cities discarded because not in the INSEE file (probably former cities)\n".format(deleted_cities))


#
# 4 Do whatever you want with the data (MERGED_DATA)
#

fieldnames = ['code_insee', 'name', 'department', 'zip_code', 'gps']
with open('french_cities_2017.csv', 'w') as csvfile:
    writer = csv.DictWriter(csvfile, delimiter=';', fieldnames=fieldnames)
    writer.writeheader()
    for code_insee, city in MERGED_DATA.items():
        for zipcode, gps in city['zipcodes'].items():
            data = {
                'code_insee': code_insee,
                'name': city['verbose_name'],
                'department': city['department'],
                'zip_code': zipcode,
                'gps': gps,
            }
            writer.writerow(data)

Output of the script:

Reading of INSEE file
    35416 cities found.

Reading of LAPOSTE file
    35416 cities found.
    267 cities discarded because of missing GPS coordinates.
    2 cities are missing in LAPOSTE file (because only present on the INSEE file, probably new cities)

Merging of INSEE and LAPOSTE files
    35414 cities merged.
    478 cities discarded because not in the INSEE file (probably former cities)

Result

You can download the result. It contains INSEE code, name, department, zip code and GPS coordinates for all french cities.

Stuffs to remember when dealing with french cities data

  • Keep the INSEE code (CODEGEO) as the key to identify a city in your system.
  • Some cities can have multiple zip codes
  • Some cities can have multiple zip codes from different departement (ex: Lajoux, Paray-Vieille-Poste)
  • Some cities no longer exist (ex: L'Hôtellerie-de-Flée, Montgellafrey)
  • Department ID can have letter (ex: 2A, 2B)
  • Some zipcode has a leading zero, therefor zipcode should be saved as string not integer.

entry.title: Nantes incubators, accelerators & more
entry.summary: What kind of help is provided for young startups in Nantes?
entry.content:
Disclaimer: All information bellow are not ordered, I don't have any preferences about startups, incubators, etc.

Introduction

I follow Nantes startup ecosystem for quite a while and lately I heard about so many new structures to help and support startups, just this year there is at least 4 new incubators! I decided to list them all in order to have a better understanding of Nantes ecosystem.

If there is any error, don't hesitate to ping me on twitter.

Incubators

  • 1kubator
    • Website: 1kubator.com/incubateur-nantes/
    • About: Incubation of 10 months. 25k€ funding. In exchange of 10% equity.
    • Startups: Take a desk, Switch up, Makidoo, ...
    • Key guy: Sandrine Charpentier
  • IMT Atlantique incubator
    • Website: incubateur.imt-atlantique.fr/home-en/
    • About: Within a high-level engineering school.
    • Startups: Meyko, Sensorwake, Shopopop, ...
    • Key guy: Régine Drouet Delhomme
  • Maia Mater
    • Website: www.maiamater.camp
    • About: Takes no equity! Free room and board. For first-time entrepreneur, just graduated or students
    • Startups: abradebarras, LocoMiam, Familicy, ...
    • Key guys: Quentin Adam, Terence Desclain
  • Novapuls
    • Website: novapuls.fr
    • About: Start first semester of 2018. Incubation of 12 months. 20k€ funding. In exchange of 1 to 2% equity. Subsidiary of Sodero Gestion (french bank).
    • Startups: –
    • Key guy: Amélie André
  • Eco Innovaition Factory
    • Website: www.atlanpole.fr/eco-innovation-factory/
    • About: Incubation of 6 months. Works closely with Atlanpole
    • Startups: EKO Verde, Akajoule, Velco, ...
    • Key guy: Samuel Bachelot
  • Octopus
    • Website: –
    • About: Manged by Lengow.
    • Startups: Dictanova, Younboost Market, Kaemo, ...
    • Key guy: Mickael Froger
  • Centrale-Audencia-ensa incubator
    • Website: innovation.audencia.com/entreprendre/incubateur-centrale-audencia-ensa-nantes/
    • About: Managed and works with severals high rank schools.
    • Startups: 10-vins, Hydrocean, Innosea, ...
    • Key guy: Aurélie Couapel
  • Labo des Ecossolies incubator
    • Website: www.ecossolies.fr/L-incubateur
    • About: Incubation of 12 months.
    • Startups: Work and co, Envie 44, Le reflet, ...
    • Key guy: Guillaume Leroux
  • Harmonie Mutuelle incubator / Creative Care Factory
    • Website: -
    • About: Focus on startups working on care, health, well-being... Co-manged by Harmonie Mutuelle and the SAMOA.
    • Startups: Atmotrack, Team officine, Mobidys
    • Key guy: -
  • NMcube / Nouveaux Médias, Nouveaux Modèles à Nantes Métropole
    • Website: -
    • About: Focus on emerging medias. Co-managed by Ouest Médialab, Creative Factory, Audencia and Polytech Nantes. Starting in january 2018 with a batch of 10 startups.
    • Startups: -
    • Key guy: Julien Kostrèche?

Accelerators

  • ADN'Booster
    • Website: www.adnbooster.fr
    • About: Acceleration of 6 months.
    • Startups: 3D Counting, Teester, Moderato, ...
    • Key guy: Anthony Gongora
  • Le Village by CA - Atlantique Vendée
    • Website: www.levillagebyca.com/village/le-village-by-ca-atlantique-vendee/
    • About: Acceleration of 2 years. Part of network "Le village by CA" created by the french bank Crédit Agricole.
    • Startups: Semoa, Stamp.yt, Enerpro, ...
    • Key guy: Nathalie Massé
  • Imagination Machine
    • Website: www.imagination-machine.com
    • About: 3-month program. 15k€ funding. In exchange for 6% equity. Silicon Valley DNA + the creative spirit of Nantes
    • Startups: –
    • Key guy: Rob Spiro
  • Millésime
    • Website: millesime.1kubator.com
    • About: Focus on wine tech. In exchange of 5% equity. Managed by 1kubator and La Vigne Numérique.
    • Startups: –
    • Key guy: –
  • OFF7
    • Website: off7.co
    • About: Acceleration of 12 months. Managed by press group Ouest France. Within the Startup Palace.
    • Startups: Kadran, Score n'co, Mediego, ...
    • Key guys: Fabrice Bazard, Florian Hervéou
  • Operation Elephant
    • Website: www.operationelephant.fr
    • About: 5 months pre-accelerator. Within the Startup Palace.
    • Startups: Smart My Data, Team officine, Eqwall, ...
    • Key guy: Florian Hervéou
  • Startup Palace accelerator
    • Website: accelerateur.startup-palace.com/en
    • About: Focus on raising money up to 1M€. Works with the fund Go Capital
    • Startups: –
    • Key guys: Antoine Dumont, Mathieu Le Gac, Benoit de la Celle
  • Creative Factory Selection
    • Website: https://www.creativefactory.info/creative-factory/
    • About: Between 6 to 9 months acceleration following by 2 years of coaching.
    • Startups: Serigrafball, Emoko, Garage Sanka
    • Key guys: Jean-Luc Charles, Fabrice Berthereaux, Sophie Maitrallain

More

Don't forget there is also some entities at a national scale not mentioned here.

  • Associations/Clusters/Networks
    • La Cantine Numérique / Atlantic2 (www.atlantic2.org)
    • ADN Ouest (www.adnouest.org)
    • La Vigne Numérique (www.lavignenumerique.org)
    • Les Sup'Porteurs de la création 44 (www.lessupporteursdelacreation44.fr)
    • Atlanpole (atlanpole.com)
    • Réseau Entreprendre Atlantique (www.reseau-entreprendre-atlantique.fr)
    • Pépinière Réseau Ouest (www.pepinieresreseauouest.fr/pepiniere-entreprise/creatic-nantes)
  • Blitzkrieg schools
    • La School (www.la-school.co)
    • Le Wagon Nantes (www.lewagon.com/nantes)
  • Funds
    • GO CAPITAL (www.gocapital.fr)
    • WEDOGOOD (www.wedogood.co)
    • Ouest Angels (ouestangels.org)
    • Atlantique Business Angels Booster (ABAB) (www.businessbooster.fr)
    • ADIE (www.adie.org)
    • Proximea (www.proximea.net)
  • Institutional organizations
    • Nantes Tech (www.nantestech.com)
    • CCI Nantes St-Nazaire (nantesstnazaire.cci.fr)
    • BGE Pays de la Loire (www.aidecreationentreprise.fr/tag/bge-pays-de-la-loire/)
    • Initiative Pays de la Loire (www.initiative-paysdelaloire.fr)
    • Pépite CRÉER (www.creer.lunam.fr)
    • Réseaux de Développement de l'Innovation Pays de la Loire (https://twitter.com/rdipdl)

Conclusion

There is so many structures to help startups that it can be difficult to find the right one. But there is definitely one out there for each startup :)

entry.title: Why I love Django
entry.content:
Because it prevents you from making bad software design decisions !

Everytime I start having headeach using Django because I try to do something not documented or not discussed on the internet, it often means that my software design is bad.

Django make you think about how you design your code in order to be clean and keep it simple!

Headeach in Django = bad software design ! :)

entry.title: Django: multiple forms in one class based view
entry.summary: How to fit several forms in one view ?
entry.content:
Context

Let's say we want to rebuild Stackoverflow and especially the page of a question. On this page you can either post a response or a comment, so here classic class based views are not enough. We will focus on those two forms (response and comment) for the example bellow.

Constraints

  • Staying on the same URL after submitting a form
  • Forms cannot be submitted at the same time
  • Using a class based view style because it seems more readable in my opinion

forms.py

from django import forms

class ResponseForm(forms.Form):
    content = forms.CharField()

class CommentForm(forms.Form):
    content = forms.CharField()

urls.py

from django.conf.urls import url

from my_app.views import QuestionDetail

urlpatterns = [
    url(r"^detail/(?P<pk>\w+)/$", QuestionDetail.as_view()),
]

views.py

from django.contrib.auth.mixins import LoginRequiredMixin
from django.http import Http404
from django.shortcuts import render
from django.views.generic import View

from my_app.forms import CommentForm, ResponseForm
from my_app.models import Question


class QuestionDetail(LoginRequiredMixin, View):
    template_name = 'my_app/question_detail.html'

    def get_object(self):
        try:
            obj = Question.objects.get(pk=self.kwargs['pk'])
        except Question.DoesNotExist:
            raise Http404('Question not found!')
        return obj

    def get_context_data(self, **kwargs):
        kwargs['question'] = self.get_object()
        if 'response_form' not in kwargs:
            kwargs['response_form'] = ResponseForm()
        if 'comment_form' not in kwargs:
            kwargs['comment_form'] = CommentForm()

        return kwargs

    def get(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        return render(request, self.template_name, self.get_context_data())

    def post(self, request, *args, **kwargs):
        ctxt = {}

        if 'response' in request.POST:
            response_form = ResponseForm(request.POST)

            if response_form.is_valid():
                    # Here, save the response
            else:
                ctxt['response_form'] = response_form

        elif 'comment' in request.POST:
            comment_form = CommentForm(request.POST)

            if comment_form.is_valid():
                    # Here, save the comment
            else:
                ctxt['comment_form'] = comment_form

        return render(request, self.template_name, self.get_context_data(**ctxt))

Here the view inherit from View in order to keep a class based view style. All methods here has been inspired by other CBV like UpdateView.

question_detail.html

<fieldset>
    <legend>Answer the question</legend>
    <form method="post">
        {% csrf_token %}
        {{ response_form }}
        <input name="response" type="submit" value="Submit" />
    </form>
</fieldset>
<fieldset>
    <legend>Add a comment</legend>
    <form method="post">
        {% csrf_token %}
        {{ comment_form }}
        <input name="comment" type="submit" value="Submit" />
    </form>
</fieldset>

For each form, in the template the should name the submit button in order to know in the view which form has been submitted.

Inspirations

While looking for a solution to handle multiple forms in one view I found these posts whose inspired me:

  • Multiple Django forms in the same view (How to know which form has been submitted)
  • Django Class-based Views with Multiple Forms (Tweak UpdateView in order the handle multiple forms)
  • Using Multiple Django Forms On One Page (Talks about saving several forms in one shot)
  • Two forms one view in django (Use multiple views to handle multiple forms, interesting approach)

entry.title: django-registration vs django-registration-redux
entry.summary: What is the difference between django-registration and django-registration-redux ?
entry.content:
TL;DR: Use django-registration-redux because the community is behind it.


I have been a bit cut off the rest of the Django's world these last years and if you have been too, you may have some difficulties to understand why there is django-registration-redux and django-registration.

So I wanted to share some clues I got. I may have missed some!

The package django-registration use to be quite useful some years ago, but it seems like James Bennett stop maintains the package for more than 2 years (2013/2014), so Andrew Cutler forks it in 2014 and rename it django-registration-redux.

A year latter James Bennett start commiting again on the django-registration package. So now we have those two packages with differents names but the same application name, it can be quite disturbing when switching projects with those two packages.

Both are now actives and seems to provide the same features, but I have chosen django-registration-redux because the community seems to be behind it. One way to see it is to take a look at the statistics:

  • django-registration-redux
    • 63 contributors
    • 125 pull requests
  • django-registration
    • 21 contributors
    • 40 pull requests

I don't know why those projects are not merged into one. I think it could be really a good thing for the community and for the maintainers of those packages to join forces to have one package :)

Anyway, thanks to James Bennett, Andrew Cutler and all contributors to provide us such good packages!

entry.title: Django authentication by email (no username)
entry.summary: How to use the email as the user identifier and no longer use the username ?
entry.content:
Goal

  • Allow user to register and log with email/password and not username/password.
  • Keep the behaviour as close as possible from Django defaults.
    • manage.py createsuperuser with email
    • Admin creation and update
  • Redefine the fewer code possible

Step 1: User model

The first thing to do is to redefine the User model. Unlike Django documentation, our model will not inherit AbstractUser, but AbstractBaseUser because we don't want the username field anymore. Except from that, all the code below is pretty much the same as AbstractUser as we can see it from Django's code. We also inherit from PermissionsMixin so we still get the permission and group feature available.

from django.db import models
from django.contrib.auth.models import AbstractBaseUser
from django.contrib.auth.models import PermissionsMixin
from django.core.mail import send_mail
from django.utils import timezone
from django.utils.translation import ugettext_lazy as _

class User(AbstractBaseUser, PermissionsMixin):

    email = models.EmailField(unique=True)
    is_staff = models.BooleanField(
        _('staff status'),
        default=False,
        help_text=_('Designates whether the user can log into this site.'),
    )
    is_active = models.BooleanField(
        _('active'),
        default=True,
        help_text=_(
            'Designates whether this user should be treated as active. '
            'Unselect this instead of deleting accounts.'
        ),
    )

    first_name = models.CharField(_('first name'), max_length=30, blank=True)
    last_name = models.CharField(_('last name'), max_length=150, blank=True)

    date_joined = models.DateTimeField(_('date joined'), default=timezone.now)

    objects = UserManager()

    USERNAME_FIELD = 'email'

    class Meta:
        verbose_name = _('user')
        verbose_name_plural = _('users')

    def clean(self):
        super().clean()
        self.email = self.__class__.objects.normalize_email(self.email)

    def get_short_name(self):
        """Return the short name for the user."""
        return self.first_name

    def email_user(self, subject, message, from_email=None, **kwargs):
        """Send an email to this user."""
        send_mail(subject, message, from_email, [self.email], **kwargs)

Once it is done, add to your setting AUTH_USER_MODEL:

AUTH_USER_MODEL = 'my_app_user.User'

Step 2: User manager

With just the model things won't work, you also need to redefine the Manager so it doesn't take into account the username anymore. Again this looks a lot like the default UserManager's code.

from django.contrib.auth.models import BaseUserManager

class UserManager(BaseUserManager):
    """Redefine user manager with email as identifier."""

    def _create_user(self, email, password, **extra_fields):
        """
        Creates and saves a User with the given email and password.
        """
        if not email:
            raise ValueError('The Email must be set')
        email = self.normalize_email(email)
        user = self.model(email=email, **extra_fields)
        user.set_password(password)
        user.save()
        return user

    def create_user(self, email, password, **extra_fields):
        extra_fields.setdefault('is_staff', False)
        extra_fields.setdefault('is_superuser', False)
        return self._create_user(email, password, **extra_fields)

    def create_superuser(self, email, password, **extra_fields):
        extra_fields.setdefault('is_staff', True)
        extra_fields.setdefault('is_superuser', True)
        return self._create_user(email, password, **extra_fields)

So now we can create superuser with :

python manage.py createsuperuser

Step 3: Admininistration

Like for the previous step, here I was inspired by default UserAdmin. I just removed all trace of username.

from django.contrib import admin
from django.contrib.auth.admin import UserAdmin as DjangoUserAdmin
from django.utils.translation import gettext_lazy as _

from user.models import User

class UserAdmin(DjangoUserAdmin):
    fieldsets = (
        (None, {'fields': ('email', 'password')}),
        (_('Personal info'), {'fields': ('first_name', 'last_name',)}),
        (_('Permissions'), {'fields': ('is_active', 'is_staff', 'is_superuser',
                                       'groups', 'user_permissions')}),
        (_('Important dates'), {'fields': ('last_login', 'date_joined')}),
    )
    add_fieldsets = (
        (None, {
            'classes': ('wide',),
            'fields': ('email', 'password1', 'password2'),
        }),
    )
    list_display = ('email', 'first_name', 'last_name', 'is_staff')
    list_filter = ('is_staff', 'is_superuser', 'is_active', 'groups')
    search_fields = ('first_name', 'last_name', 'email')
    ordering = ('email',)
    filter_horizontal = ('groups', 'user_permissions',)

admin.site.register(User, UserAdmin)

Conclusion

We got an authentification closed to Django's defaults but with email and no longer with username.

The only thing missing is to regroup in the administration the User and Group. I didn't find any simple way to do it.

Inspirations

  • https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/contrib/auth/models.py
  • https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/contrib/auth/base_user.py
  • https://medium.com/@ramykhuffash/django-authentication-with-just-an-email-and-password-no-username-required-33e47976b517
  • https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/topics/auth/customizing/#substituting-a-custom-user-model

entry.title: Django 1.11, CSRF token, template & function view
entry.summary: How to have a CSRF token in your function view's template ?
entry.content:
The goal

In one of my project I wanted to handle a view with a function, and this view had to handle a form and render HTML through a template. Pretty classic... but I had trouble to add the CSRF token!

Try number 1: @csrf_protect decorator

I first thought I had to add the famous decorator like this :

from django.http import HttpResponse
from django.template import loader
from django.views.decorators.csrf import csrf_protect

@csrf_protect
def home(request):
    t = loader.get_template('my_page.html')
    context = {}
    return HttpResponse(t.render(context))

The {%csrf_token %} in my template didn't render anything, ok, that's a fail.

Try number 2: RequestContext to the rescue

I started looking at the documentation and I found this: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/ref/csrf/#how-to-use-it

It said:

In the corresponding view functions, ensure that RequestContext is used to render the response so that {% csrf_token %} will work properly. If you're using the render() function, generic views, or contrib apps, you are covered already since these all use RequestContext.

Ok, so let's try with a RequestContext:

from django.http import HttpResponse
from django.template import RequestContext, loader
from django.views.decorators.csrf import csrf_protect

@csrf_protect
def home(request):
    t = loader.get_template('my_page.html')
    context = {}
    request_context = RequestContext(request, context)
    return HttpResponse(t.render(request_context))

This time a got a error 500, damned... The error says: "context must be a dict rather than RequestContext." Ok, you want a dict but the documentation said I need to have a RequestContext, dafuq ?

Try number 3: Template and Template, the subtile difference

After looking to a lot of documentation, stackoverflow questions and Django's code itself. I found a solution, I don't know if it is the better, but it works:

from django.http import HttpResponse
from django.template import RequestContext, loader
from django.views.decorators.csrf import csrf_protect

@csrf_protect
def home(request):
    t = loader.get_template('my_page.html')
    context = {}
    request_context = RequestContext(request, context)
    return HttpResponse(t.template.render(request_context))

The important thing here is t.template! The object t is an instance of django.template.backends.django.Template and the object t.template is an instance of django.template.base.Template which accepts RequestContext!

I hope this will help you save some time!

entry.title: Virtualenvwraper with shared hosting on alwaysdata.com
entry.summary: How to install virtualenvwrapper on shared hosting on alwaywasdata ?
entry.content:
Installation of virtualenvwrapper

In your console type :

pip install virtualenvwrapper

Enable virtualenvwrapper with ZSH + Oh My Zsh

In order to use ZSH you should go to the adminstration panel (Remote access > SSH). Then with Oh My Zsh, you can use the virtualenvwrapper plugin by adding this into your .zshrc file :

export PATH=$PATH:$HOME/.local/bin

And activate your plugin :

plugins=(git virtualenvwrapper)

Enable virtualenvwrapper with other shells

Edit ~/.bashrc (or your startup shell script) and add:

export WORKON_HOME=$HOME/.virtualenvs
source $HOME/.local/bin/virtualenvwrapper.sh

entry.title: Protect Django media files per user basis with nginx
entry.summary: How can you control access to django media files ?
entry.content:
Use case

A service with Django where user can upload files and you want to be sure that they can only access to their own files and not the files from other users.

In this example, I am using nginx but this solution can be adapted to other http servers.

Step 1: All requests for media should go throught a specific view

Edit file myproject/urls.py and add:

from myproject.views import media_access

urlpatterns = [
    ...,
    url(r'^media/(?P<path>.*)', media_access, name='media'),
]

Step 2: Add the view and check access

Add the following view in myproject/views.py:

from django.http import HttpResponse
from django.http import HttpResponseForbidden

def media_access(request, path):
    """
    When trying to access :
    myproject.com/media/uploads/passport.png

    If access is authorized, the request will be redirected to
    myproject.com/protected/media/uploads/passport.png

    This special URL will be handle by nginx we the help of X-Accel
    """

    access_granted = False

    user = request.user
    if user.is_authenticated():
        if user.is_staff:
            # If admin, everything is granted
            access_granted = True
        else:
            # For simple user, only their documents can be accessed
            user_documents = [
                user.identity_document,
                # add here more allowed documents
            ]

            for doc in user_documents:
                if path == doc.name:
                    access_granted = True

    if access_granted:
        response = HttpResponse()
        # Content-type will be detected by nginx
        del response['Content-Type']
        response['X-Accel-Redirect'] = '/protected/media/' + path
        return response
    else:
        return HttpResponseForbidden('Not authorized to access this media.')

Here the important part is about the variable user_documents. It should contain reference to all files the user has access. In my case I extended the User model to add a field identity_document that why I can access it here.

In this media_acces view, you can implement any authorization logic.

Step 3: Configure nginx

Here is a full example of nginx configuration. The important part is about location /protected/. We suppose that Django is available with Gunicorn on port 8080 for example.

upstream myprojectapp {
  server localhost:8080;
}

server {
    listen 80;

    server_name myproject.com;

    server_name_in_redirect on;
    error_log /var/log/nginx/myproject-error.log crit;
    access_log  /var/log/nginx/myproject-access.log custom_combined;

    root /path/to/my/django/project/static;

    location ^~ /static/ {
        alias /path/to/my/django/project/static/;
    }

    location /protected/ {
        internal;
        alias /path/to/my/django/project/;
    }

    location / {
        include proxy_params;
        proxy_pass http://myprojectapp;
        proxy_buffering off;
    }

}

You can notice there is no location ^~ /media/ that's because this URL is handle by django.

Conclusion

You have seen how quickly you can protect your media files taking advantage of Django to handle the authorization and of nginx to serve files :)

You can find more informations about X-accel on nginx website: https://www.nginx.com/resources/wiki/start/topics/examples/x-accel/
